did.unittitle: Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy, records, 1923-2006

bioghist.head: Historical or Biographical Note

note.p: The historical or biographical note provides background information about the creator of the material. It does not indicate the contents of the collection. Description of collection contents are found in the Collection and Series level Scope and Contents notes.

bioghist.p: The Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy, established in 1933, is the oldest school of international affairs in the United States devoted exclusively to graduate study.

scopecontent.head: Collection Scope and Content

note.p: The collection scope and content note provides general information about the contents of the collection. More detailed information about the collection can be found in Series Descriptions.

scopecontent.p: This collection contains reports, correspondence, annual meeting materials, publications, and photographs related to the history of the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy.

Some images have been cataloged at the item level as part of the University Image collection. The photographs have been cataloged to the folder level, but the remainder of the material is only minimally processed and may not be available for research. Please contact the DCA office for more information.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: Some records may be restricted. See the DCA's General Policy on Access for more information about access to records, especially official University records.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use
userestrict.p: Some material may be copyrighted or restricted. It is the patron's obligation to determine and satisfy copyright or other case restrictions when publishing or otherwise distributing materials found in the collections. Please see the DCA's policy on Copyright and Fair Use for more information.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy, records, 1923-2006, Digital Collections and Archives, Tufts University

controlaccess.head: Organizations:
controlaccess.corpname: Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy

note.p: The series description provides more detailed information about the contents of each individual series. For a more general description of the collection as a whole, please see the Collection Scope and Content note.

scopecontent.p: Photographs of Fletcher faculty, staff, students, and alumni. Also included are photos of events and speakers, as well as Fletcher facilities.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Materials are grouped by document type and remain in the order created by Russell Miller.

note.p: The series description provides more detailed information about the contents of each individual series. For a more general description of the collection as a whole, please see the Collection Scope and Content note.

scopecontent.p: This series contains subject files assembled by Russell Miller in his research for Light on the Hill. Most of the material dates between the 1920s and the 1960s, although some information from the 1980s is included. Correspondence accounts for the majority of the material. Materials include President Cousens' correspondence regarding the evolution of the school in the 1920s, and correspondence from Dean Hoskins, President Carmichael, and Vice President/Provost Mead. Also includes files on special programs, such as the Latin American Teaching Fellowships, proposed curricular changes, "centers" within the school such as the Murrow Center, and special events. Includes brochures and clippings. These files were left in the order established by Russell Miller.

The bulk of these materials are from 1950 to 1970. These files were received in alphabetical order by correspondent, and this order has been maintained.

scopecontent.p: Materials from the office of the dean of the Fletcher School dealing with subjects such as ARMS control, energy policy and the Grew Program. The bulk of these materials date from 1960 to 1976. These files were arranged in alphabetical order by subject when they were received, and this order has been maintained.

scopecontent.p: This series is comprised of files from the office of the dean of the Fletcher School that deal with organizations with which the Fletcher School interacted. The organizations represented in this file range from those with which the Fletcher School had joint educational enterprises (including the Harvard Law School, which was also a parent institution to the Fletcher School), to those with whom they had grant funding or other philanthropic relationships. These materials were received in alphabetical order by organization, and this order has been maintained.

scopecontent.p: Includes Historical Note and Series Description

SERIES DESCRIPTION This series contains files relating to the Fletcher School's Board of Overseers, formerly Board of Visitors, from 1950-2005. The bulk of the material consists of board member files and meeting files. Board member files include biographical material, recruitment files, and correspondence. The meeting files document annual meetings such as correspondence, meeting minutes, scheduling and preparation material, and presentation packets for board members.

HISTORICAL NOTE In 1929, the President of Tufts University, John C. Cousens, began recruiting prominent individuals to the Board of Advisors of the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy, though the school itself did not open until 1933. President Cousens hoped that the members would assist in the development of the Fletcher School and that they eventually would form its Board of Visitors. In its earliest conception, the Board of Advisors would be made up of people with an interest in international affairs who were not trustees of Tufts nor affiliated with the College.

However, it was not until 1940 that the Trustees of Tufts College formally established the Board of Counselors for the Fletcher School. Five years later, the Board was enlarged from its original four members and was renamed as the Board of Advisors. Though the members were distinguished officials in government and diplomacy, there were no specific mandates or guidelines in place for their role at Fletcher.
In 1958, Tufts College issued a memorandum specifying the responsibilities of Committees of Visitors for each school; at Fletcher this Committee of Visitors was called the Board of Advisors.

The objectives of each Committee were to provide ongoing evaluations of their School; to define its needs; and advise the administration in regards to that School. It was recommended that the "core" of each Board or Committee (including Fletcher's) should consist of members of the Board of Trustees, with other members appointed upon the president's recommendation.

In 1969, the new Chair of the Fletcher Board, Charles Adams, attempted to revitalize the Board by defining its duties and activities. Two yearly meetings were proposed-one in the fall to be held at the Fletcher School so Board members could meet with students and faculty and a spring meeting to deal with the business and operational aspects of the School. During the 1970s, Tufts University altered the responsibilities of oversight as well as the membership of each committee for all Schools but Fletcher. At the request of Charles Adams, the Fletcher School was allowed to operate independently of the new regulations. At the time, the Board was called Board of Visitors, and Tufts Trustees extended an invitation to Fletcher's Board of Visitors to join the Trustees in order to create a bridge between the two governing bodies.

During the 1980s, the Fletcher School was more closely integrated with the rest of Tufts University under the leadership of its dean, Theodore Eliot, Jr. and Tufts' President Jean Mayer. In the mid-1990s, the Fletcher Board of Visitors took the name Board of Overseers. They meet 2-3 times per year, in the spring, fall, and/or winter. Though the responsibilities of the Overseers remain flexible, they are primarily involved with the management and development of Fletcher and working with the Asian, European, Latin American and International Management advisory groups.
Sources:
BOV History, 1982, 1995. Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy, records, 1923-2005. Digital Collections and Archives. Tufts University.
Concise Encyclopedia of Tufts History. Tufts Digital Library. Tufts University.
Gittleman, Sol. An Entrepreneurial University: The Transformation of Tufts, 1976-2002 (Medford, MA: Tufts University Press, 2004)

note.p: The series description provides more detailed information about the contents of each individual series. For a more general description of the collection as a whole, please see the Collection Scope and Content note.

scopecontent.p: This series includes materials from various projects and special programs sponsored by the Fletcher School. These materials date between 1949 and 1988. Projects that are represented include the Niger Livestock Development Program, the Latin American Teaching Fellowship Program, the Venezuelan-American Conference of 1975, the program on East/West Cooperation, and the Program in Law and Population. These materials are arranged in alphabetical order within each project. This series includes materials in languages other than English including French, German, Russian, and Spanish.
